Situation1: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: The weekly study circle meets tonight to discuss a chapter they have not yet reviewed.
Story: I glance at the clock on my laptop, feeling the familiar tug of tension in my chest. The team meeting is about to start—just a routine catch-up, but my manager always expects everyone to show up and participate, even if the session is recorded. I know my absence will be noticed, and I don’t want to let my colleagues down or seem disengaged. At the same time, tonight is the weekly Buddhist study circle, and we’re finally discussing a chapter I’ve been waiting for. The group relies on each member’s presence and insight, and I feel a deep responsibility to contribute, not just for myself but for the collective growth. My mind races, torn between the professional expectation to be a reliable teammate and the spiritual commitment to my sangha. I can almost hear the gentle voices of my fellow practitioners, inviting me to reflect, while the ping of my work chat reminds me of my obligations. The weight of these conflicting roles presses on me, and I sit frozen, uncertain which path to honor tonight.
